answers.answer: It's unlikely that your heart function would return to normal post-op but there may actually be some improvement with surgery.  The surgical risks are higher and there are no guarantees but my opinion is that it may be worth a try.  I would recommend coming here for a second opinion concerning surgery.  You can call the number below and make an appointment with one of the F15 "valve" cardiologists such as Dr. Stewart.

Dear Lorraine,Go with the dr.s suggestion and get the 2nd opinion!  My mother was 65 with diabetes and chf, she was so bad off they had a panel of dr.s to determine whether to do the valve replacement or not and they took a week deciding!!!  They opted to go ahead and we made 10 more years of memories with my mom!  Good Luck!

Lorraine, I'm 4 years older, and my EF is only 25%, but the rest of your cardiac description is almost identical to mine.  Now add diabetes and a history of cancer.  I find out the final results of everything (heartwise) in 2 more days. Remember, M.D. does not spell G.O.D.; doctors are people capable of making judgement errors just like the rest of us and new meds and treatments are sometimes hard to keep up with, so to paraphrase Shakespeare, "get thee to a cardiac specialist STAT!"  Good luck!

question: Thank you for the opportunity to post here.  I was diagnosed with valvular heart disease, dilated cardiomyopathy and CHF about one year ago.  My left ventricle is dilated to 6.2 with hypertrophy, and I also have global hypokinesis.  I have just turned 40.  My EF runs between 35 and 40 according to echo.  I have been told that I cannot have valve replacement.  My condition is maintained by meds. Digoxin, Aldactone, Prinivil and Demadex.  I have three valves that are regurgitant: Mitral-moderate to severe, Aortic-mild, Tricuspid-Moderate.  The valvular disease is primary and the cardiomyopathy is secondary.  I don't understand why I can't have the valves replaced.  Wouldn't that cure my condition?  When is it to late for a replacement?  If I can't have replacement, how long is it before this condition would worsen and I would require possibly a heart transplant?   Thank you for your time and consideration in answering my questions.
title: When is it to late for valve replacement surgery?
